description: French, from Provençal gavoto (“dance of the mountain people”), from Old Occitan Gavot (“Alp native”), literally “glutton, boor,” from gaver (“force feed”), from Old Provençal gava (“crop”); attested since the 1690s.

entries.meaning: A French dance, in either 4/4 or 2/2 time.

verbs.description: gavotte (third-person singular simple present gavottes, present participle gavotting, simple past and past participle gavotted)
